sect1.title: 39 Escherichia and Shigella

para.phrase: ROMNEY M. HUMPHRIES, MATTHEW L. FARON, JOHN P. DEKKER, NATHAN A. LEDEBOER, AND BLAKE W. BUCHAN

sect1.para: Members of the generaEscherichia and Shigella are most often associated with infections of the gastrointestinal (GI) and urinary tracts, but may also cause more severe systemic or invasive infections including pneumonia, sepsis, and meningitis. This chapter provides an overview of each genus and discusses key aspects of taxonomy, epidemiology, and virulence, along with culture-dependent and culture-independent methodologies for the identification and classification of species within these genera. In addition, recent trends in antimicrobial resistance patterns and updates to recommended susceptibility testing modalities and interpretive criteria are discussed to understand the current best practice for treating active infections.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The genusEscherichia is taxonomically located within the order Enterobacterales, family Enterobacteriaceae. Escherichia coli is the type species and was first described in 1884 during studies of the intestinal microbiota of neonates. Five additional species—Escherichia albertii, Escherichia fergusonii, Escherichia vulneris, Escherichia hermannii, and Escherichia blattae—were initially assigned to the genus (1, 2); however, E. blattae has since been reclassified as Shimwellia blattae and removed from the genus (3). In recent years, two additional novel species of Escherichia have been proposed based on genetic analysis: Escherichia marmotae, originally isolated from fecal samples obtained from wild marmots in China (4), and Escherichia ruysiae, which has been isolated from human stool but was previously assigned to an unnamed Escherichia lineage (5). Both species are now formally recognized taxonomically, bringing the current number of species within the genus Escherichia to seven. Historically, Escherichia species were differentiated from other Enterobacterales and each other based on phenotypic properties such as biochemical reactivity and physical characteristics such as motility and colony pigmentation. However, similarities in physical and biochemical properties between species hinder accurate phylogeny and identification when used as the sole basis for characterization of isolates (1, 6).

Molecular techniques such as G+C content analysis, DNA-DNA hybridization, and nucleic acid sequence analysis have enabled more accurate phylogenetic studies. The G+C content amongE. coli falls in a narrow range between 48 and 52%, which is similar to that of Salmonella, Shigella, and Erwinia (7, 8). Genomes of Escherichia species range from 4.5 Mbp to 5.7 Mbp in size and encode 4,157 to 5,315 genes (9). DNA-DNA hybridization that assesses large regions of the bacterial chromosome can provide species-level resolution within the genus. A threshold of >70% nucleic acid association between isolates has been established as defining a species (10). Association values among a diverse collection of E. coli isolates of human and animal origin ranged from 85 to 99% (7). Among Escherichia, E. coli and E. fergusonii share the highest association value (60–65%), while association values between E. coli and E. hermannii, and E. coli and E. vulneris, range from 31 to 45% (2, 11). In contrast, isolates of Shigella boydii, Shigella dysenteriae, Shigella flexneri, and Shigella sonnei exhibit association values of 80 to 89% with E. coli, supporting a close taxonomic relationship between these genera (7, 12).

The close taxonomic relationship betweenE. coli and Shigella is also apparent when utilizing nucleic acid sequence-based methods. Targeted and whole-genome sequence analysis indicates a closer relationship between Shigella spp. and E. coli than between E. coli and other Escherichia species (9, 13–15). Phylogeny based on seven conserved “housekeeping” genes resulted in clusters of each Shigella species interspersed among E. coli serotypes, while other Escherichia species were more distantly related (9). Genetic analysis based on highly conserved tuf (elongation factor Tu) and atpD (F-ATPase β-subunit) further supports a close relationship between E. coli, E. fergusonii, and Shigella species, and places E. hermannii and E. vulneris in closer taxonomic proximity to the genus Enterobacter (16).

The pan-genome ofE. coli comprises >75,000 unique gene families; however, only approximately 2,400 (3.2%) make up the core genome found in >99% of isolates (17). The wide diversity of nonpathogenic and pathogenic E. coli types has driven additional taxonomic study within this species. Five major “phylogroups” (A, B1, B2, D, E, and F) have been proposed based upon sequence homology of seven housekeeping genes (13, 15). Phylogroups are only loosely correlated with pathogenicity; however, phylogroup A contains primarily commensal strains while other phylogroups are composed primarily of pathogens (14, 15). For example, 72 to 85% of E. coli isolates from extraintestinal infections belong to phylogroup B2 (18). Molecular phylogeny indicates that specific pathogenic E. coli types (pathovars) including enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC), Shiga toxin-producing E. coli (STEC), enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC), and E. coli serotype K1 arose independently in multiple phylogroups (14, 15). These data suggest that horizontal gene transfer is the main driver of genetic diversity and virulence, as opposed to random mutation events and selective pressure (15). Horizontal transfer of genes or multigene cassettes enables the transformation of nonpathogenic E. coli to a specific pathovar. For example, transfer of genes encoding heat-stable (ST) and heat-labile (LT) enterotoxin has the potential to transform nonpathogenic E. coli to enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) regardless of lineage (9, 13). The genomes of pathogenic E. coli such as STEC serotype O157, uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC), and EPEC are approximately 1 Mb larger than their commensal counterparts, owing to the acquisition of additional genes required for virulence (9, 19).

Transfer of virulence-associated genes amongE. coli pathovars is evident in phylogenetic trees based on whole-genome analysis, in which pathovars sharing specific virulence genes or toxins cluster together independent of the relatedness of housekeeping gene sequences (9, 13). Unrelated pathovars share approximately 50% genome similarity but are defined by a small set of pathovar-specific genes ranging from 120 for STEC to 45 for UPEC and just 3 to 6 for EPEC and ETEC (19). These genes encode pili, toxins, or secretion systems related to the pathogenesis of the pathovar. Pathovar clustering is most pronounced among STEC isolates, which also cluster closely with Shigella dysenteriae. The frequency of horizontal recombination events between strains and a relatively small “core” chromosome presents a barrier to the development of a simple evolutionary tree for this species.

sect1.title: Description of the Genus
sect1.para: Escherichia spp. are facultative anaerobic, non-spore-forming Gram-negative bacilli 1–3 μm in length and 0.5 μm in diameter, although this can be impacted by temperature, growth state, and exposure to antibiotics (20). Among motile species, multiple axial flagella mediate motility in liquid (swimming) and semisolid (swarming) matrices. Encapsulated E. coli strains are identified by their K-antigen type. These strains demonstrate increased serum resistance and are more frequently associated with extraintestinal infections. Escherichia spp. are easily cultivated on routine laboratory media including Trypticase soy agar (TSA) with or without blood supplement, MacConkey agar (MAC), Trypticase soy broth (TSB), and various differential and selective media commonly utilized in the laboratory (see “Isolation Procedures” below). Colonies appear round, smooth, convex, and gray in color with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm after 18 to 24 h of incubation at 35°C. Some but not all isolates may demonstrate a narrow zone of beta-hemolysis. Biochemically, > 95% of E. coli isolates ferment lactose to acid end products with production of gas, are positive for indole production and lysine decarboxylase, reduce nitrate to nitrite, and exhibit negative reactions for oxidase, esculin, and urease (Table 1). Approximately 5% of E. coli isolates are considered “nonreactive” and yield negative reactions for lactose fermentation, indole production, and other biochemical tests commonly used for bacterial identification. These isolates are difficult to differentiate from Shigella spp. based on biochemical reactions and may require serotyping. Other Escherichia spp. have biochemical profiles that differ from that of E. coli, but are similar to other members of the family Enterobacteriaceae, resulting in difficulty in identification or misidentification if biochemical tests are solely relied on (1, 21, 22).

sect1.title: Epidemiology and Transmission
sect1.para: Escherichia spp. exist largely as asymptomatic colonizers of insects, birds, and mammals; however, some species or strains possess sets of virulence factors that enable them to cause gastrointestinal, urinary, or other extraintestinal disease. The primary route of transmission is fecal-oral, including indirect transmission via fecally contaminated food or water. Within the genus Escherichia, the various pathovars of E. coli cause >99% of human disease associated with the genus. The primary reservoir for E. coli is the small and large intestine of mammals, including humans, where they are among the most frequently isolated facultative anaerobic species. The ability to easily culture E. coli from stool has led to the perception that it is the dominant bacterial species present; however, E. coli comprises only 0.1% or less of the total gut microbiome in healthy humans (23).

Isolation ofE. coli from environmental soil and water specimens is used as an indicator of fecal contamination (24), which can be an important source of transmission for diarrheagenic pathovars. E. coli can persist in surface water for 5 to 15 days and in soil or sediment for 40 days or longer (25). In agricultural regions of India and Southeast Asia with poor sanitation, over 25% of water sources used for human consumption contain diarrheagenic E. coli (25). In these regions, pathogenic E. coli is the third or fourth leading cause of infectious diarrhea in children, with an incidence of 1 to 2 cases/100 child years (26). In the United States, diarrheagenic E. coli infections combine for >200,000 cases of infectious diarrhea per year (27). Most of these infections (60 to 80%) are foodborne, and the most common vehicle for infection is undercooked meat, typically beef contaminated with intestinal contents during slaughter and processing. E. coli can also persist on fresh fruit or vegetables tainted with contaminated soil or water, and outbreaks have been attributed to prepackaged vegetables sold direct to consumers or used by restaurant chains (28). Specifically, Shiga toxin-producing E. coli account for approximately 10% of bacterial foodborne outbreaks, 15% of hospitalizations, and 10% of deaths associated with bacterial gastroenteritis in the United States (29). The infectious dose for diarrheagenic E. coli pathovars ranges from as little as 10 to 100 CFU for STEC to >106 CFU for EPEC, EIEC, ETEC, and enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) (28, 30).

E. coli is the leading cause of urinary tract infections (UTI) in women of childbearing age, accounting for over 75% of infections (~10 million infections/year in the United States) (31). The primary source of infection is migration of colonizing bacteria from the gastrointestinal tract to the urethra and ascension to the bladder. Significant risk factors for uncomplicated UTI include female gender, frequent sexual intercourse, and a history of UTI.

In addition to infections of the gastrointestinal and urinary tract,E. coli can cause invasive wound, central nervous system (CNS), and bloodstream infections. E. coli is a leading cause of bloodstream infection globally, accounting for 17 to 33% of all bacterial bloodstream infections, and is particularly common in community-onset infections and in persons >65 years of age (32). Among neonates, E. coli accounts for up to 45% of cases of early-onset meningitis, particularly in preterm and low-birthweight babies (33, 34).

The epidemiology ofEscherichia species other than E. coli is not as well understood. These species are also commensals of the gastrointestinal tract but are more commonly found in birds, insects, or mammals other than humans.

sect2.title: Escherichia Species Other than E. coli
sect2.para: Escherichia species other than E. coli were recognized only within the past 30 to 40 years and have only infrequently been identified as the cause of human infections. Recent advances in bacterial identification methods such as matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight mass spectrometry (MALDI-TOF MS) and PCR sequencing have enabled recognition and raised awareness of these species in human infections.

E. albertii is the Escherichia species most closely related to E. coli, sharing 54 to 60% genetic homology, and is increasingly recognized as an important cause of gastrointestinal infections in humans. The primary reservoir for E. albertii appears to be wild birds and raccoons, in addition to chickens raised for human consumption (35, 36). Phenotypic traits including a lack of motility, failure to ferment lactose, and variable indole production make it easy to differentiate from E. coli but difficult to differentiate from other Enterobacteriaceae including Hafnia and Shigella (37, 38). Two large studies found that 14 to 19% of enteropathogenic or Shiga toxin-producing E. coli isolates from diarrheal stools were actually E. albertii, based on gene-specific PCR and multilocus sequence typing (37, 38). These data suggest that the incidence of E. albertii as an enteric pathogen has historically been underestimated. All E. albertii strains encode the intimin protein (eaeA), which mediates bacterial adhesion to the intestinal epithelium (37, 38). In addition, 85 to 96% of E. albertii isolates contain cdtB, a cytolethal distending toxin found in both Clostridioides difficile and STEC, and 4 to 10% contain the Shiga-like toxin stx2f characteristic of STEC (37–39). Isolates encoding stx2 have been associated with severe, bloody diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome (39). These isolates may be sorbitol positive or negative and will be detected using latex agglutination or ELISA tests for Shiga toxin (37, 38). E. albertii is primarily associated with acute gastroenteritis, including several foodborne outbreaks, and has been only rarely isolated from infections outside the gastrointestinal tract (40, 41).

E. fergusonii is associated with asymptomatic carriage in chickens, turkeys, pigs, and other livestock. While it is rarely isolated from human infections, one study identified E. fergusonii in 11% of positive urine specimens collected from patients with symptoms of UTI (22, 42). E. fergusonii has also been recovered from stool specimens in patients with diarrhea and, rarely, from bloodstream and traumatic wound infections (22, 43). A recent case report associated E. fergusonii with hemolytic uremic syndrome secondary to urinary tract and bloodstream infection in an elderly female; however, production of Shiga toxin was not detected in the isolate (44). Genetic orthologs encoding ST and LT enterotoxin, intimin (eaeA), and pili present in pathogenic E. coli have been identified in some E. fergusonii isolates, but definitive mutational studies to confirm the functionality of these genes are lacking (22). Further, up to 47% of isolates do not contain identifiable virulence-associated genes. Taken together, this complicates the interpretation of clinical significance when E. fergusonii is isolated from a nonsterile site. If deemed significant, susceptibility testing should be conducted to guide therapy, since multidrug resistance including extended-spectrum β-lactamase (ESBL)-positive isolates has been described (22).

E. hermannii displays a characteristic yellow pigment that differentiates it from the other Escherichia species (11). Isolation of E. hermannii from clinical specimens remains rare, and it is often recovered in conjunction with other established pathogens in polymicrobial wound cultures or other nonsterile specimens such as stool and sputum (11, 45). Over half of all invasive infections attributed to E. hermannii are bacteremia, which is more frequent in patients with indwelling venous catheters (46). Other infections including pyelonephritis, meningitis, and soft-tissue infections remain extremely rare and have been reported primarily in the elderly or those with underlying impaired immune function including chronic kidney disease, diabetes, or malignancy. Isolates of E. hermannii are uniformly resistant to penicillin, ampicillin, and amoxicillin. Resistance to tetracycline, quinolones, aminoglycosides, cephalosporins (including ESBL phenotype), and carbapenems has been reported in 14 to 33% of isolates (46).

E. vulneris shares genetic and clinical characteristics with E. hermannii (47). While E. vulneris is infrequently found in clinical specimens, 74% of isolates are recovered from wounds and 10% are recovered from respiratory sources (47). In these instances, E. vulneris has not been isolated in pure culture nor demonstrated to be the primary pathogen. Further, E. vulneris is not lethal in intraperitoneal infection models in mice (47). These factors cast doubt on the clinical significance of E. vulneris when isolated from nonsterile sites. Rare instances of invasive infection, including bacteremia, osteomyelitis, and meningitis, have been reported and are associated with immune compromise or indwelling medical devices (48–50). A case of acute gastroenteritis followed by bacteremia in an infant has been reported (48). Isolates of E. vulneris may be resistant to penicillins but appear largely susceptible to β-lactam/β-lactamase inhibitor combinations, cephalosporins, quinolones, and tetracyclines (51).

E. marmotae was first isolated in 2012 from the stool of Himalayan marmots (4). To date there are no reported cases of human infection, though orthologs of genes encoding secretion systems, invasins, enterotoxins, and other host cell modulators present in Shigella and E. coli pathovars have been identified by whole-genome sequence analysis (52).

E. ruysiae was included with other unnamed Escherichia belonging to two phylogenetic groups referred to as “cryptic clades” but was formally recognized as a novel species in 2021. The type strain was isolated from a stool specimen obtained from a patient with recent history of diarrhea, though definitive association of the bacterium with these symptoms was inconclusive (5). Whole-genome sequencing failed to identify any specific virulence genes, but several genes encoding antibiotic resistance including ESBL were noted. Both commercially available MALDI-TOF MS systems misidentify this species as E. coli with a high confidence score; however, E. ruysiae may be differentiated based on biochemical reactivity including an inability to decarboxylate lysine.

sect3.title: Extraintestinal Pathogenic E. coli (ExPEC)
sect3.para: The majority ofE. coli are nonpathogenic while contained within the intestinal lumen; however, specific groups of E. coli contain virulence factors that aid in dissemination, persistence, or pathogenesis outside the GI tract. Combined, these are referred to as extraintestinal pathogenic E. coli (ExPEC). Two major groups or pathovars of ExPEC are the UPEC and the meningitis/sepsis-associated E. coli (MNEC). Both ExPEC pathovars contain similar virulence factors and reside primarily within E. coli phylogroup B2. These pathovars can cause infections in a healthy host, for example, uncomplicated UTI; several factors potentiate infection, such as the presence of indwelling urinary catheters, immunocompromised state, and inoculation to normally sterile sites via surgery or traumatic injury. A third group of ExPEC, the septicemia-associated E. coli (SEPEC), has recently been proposed. Like UPEC and MNEC, SEPEC harbor additional virulence factors that aid in potentiation of infections outside the gastrointestinal tract (53); however, taxonomically the SEPEC are distributed across all E. coli phylogroups (A, B1, B2, D, E, F) (54). Within the hospital environment, ExPEC are a leading cause of UTI (52%), are second behind only S. aureus in bloodstream infections (25%) and skin/soft tissue infections (14%), and are fourth behind Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Klebsiella pneumoniae as a cause of lower respiratory infections (9%) (55).

sect3.title: Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC)
sect3.para: Urinary tract infections are extremely common, affecting an estimated 150 million people worldwide on an annual basis. This includes 10 to 13 million cases/year in the United States alone, where UTI accounts for nearly 1% of all outpatient physician visits (31, 56). The majority are uncomplicated UTI in sexually active females of reproductive age, but approximately 10% are classified as complicated UTI due to recurrence, infections in men, persons with urinary tract abnormalities, or persons with indwelling urinary catheters. Catheter-associated UTI (CAUTI) is among the most common hospital-acquired infections (HAIs), accounting for 12 to 17% of all HAIs (57); however, in contrast to uncomplicated UTI, E. coli represents only 12 to 35% of CAUTI, with other Enterobacterales, Pseudomonas, and Enterococcus comprising the majority of infections (58, 59). Importantly, despite causing a relative minority of CAUTI, E. coli accounts for 40 to 70% of all cases of CAUTI-associated bacteremia (57). Further, 60 to 80% of inpatients with an indwelling catheter receive antibiotics, which results in the selection or development of highly resistant isolates. While resistance rates differ by hospital and geographic location, resistance to commonly utilized antibiotics ranges from 18 to 60% among hospital-acquired UTI isolates, and in one study the presence of ESBL was identified in over 25% of isolates (60).

A specific pathovar, UPEC is the most common cause of both uncomplicated and complicated UTI (31). Infections are largely localized to the lower urinary tract (e.g., urethritis) and bladder (e.g., cystitis); however, if left untreated, 1 to 2% of infections can ascend to the kidneys, resulting in acute pyelonephritis and urosepsis (56, 61). Up to 80% of pyelonephritis is caused by UPEC (61). Those at highest risk for pyelonephritis include the elderly, pregnant females, persons with immunosuppressive conditions such as diabetes mellitus and malignancy, persons with anatomic or functional abnormality such as vesicoureteral reflux or neurogenic bladder, and persons with indwelling devices such as urinary catheters (61).

UPEC strains share a set of specific virulence factors that are largely absent from otherE. coli pathovars, which aid in adhesion, migration, and persistence within the urinary tract. Type 1 pili (e.g., fimH mannose-binding pili) are expressed by both UPEC and nonpathogenic E. coli isolates; however, they play a critical role in initial attachment to uroepithelial cells and are central to the pathogenesis of UPEC. Pyelonephritis-associated pili (e.g., papA, papG) are unique to UPEC and are present in approximately 80% of isolates obtained from patients with acute pyelonephritis (56). Additional specific virulence factors including cytotoxins, hemolysin, and iron acquisition systems are more commonly found in UPEC than in fecal E. coli isolates (56).

Though UPEC cannot be phenotypically differentiated from otherE. coli, 70 to 80% of UPEC belong to one of eight lipopolysaccharide O antigen serogroups (O1, O2, O4, O6, O7, O16, O18, O75). Of particular interest is E. coli strain type 131 (ST131), which was initially recognized in 2008 and now accounts for 22 to 66% of all E. coli isolates producing ESBLs (62). E. coli ST131 is predominantly isolated from extraintestinal infections and is prevalent in UTIs, including those that progress to urosepsis. Intestinal carriage of ST131 among healthy individuals may be as high as 2%, and the incidence of infection with the ST131 clone appears to be similar among both health care-related and community-acquired infections (63). ST131 comprises a separate lineage and serogroup (O25) but shares many of the same virulence determinants as prototypical UPEC, including fimH (100%) and papA (95%) (62, 64). Antibiotic resistance is conferred by the presence of a plasmid harboring blaCTX-M-15 ESBL in addition to genes encoding resistance to fluoroquinolones and aminoglycosides. Globally, 25 to 70% of ESBL-producing urinary isolates and 20 to 60% of ESBL-producing bloodstream isolates belong to ST131 (62).

sect3.title: Meningitis/Sepsis-Associated E. coli (MNEC)
sect3.para: Neonatal meningitis has an incidence of 0.3 per 1,000 live births in developed countries and up to 6.1 per 1,000 in the developing world (33). These infections are more prevalent in patients with perinatal risk factors such as preterm birth, low birth weight, and obstetric complications. Following the adoption of screening and intrapartum prophylaxis for group B streptococci, E. coli has become the leading cause of early-onset meningitis, accounting for 30 to 45% of total infections and 50 to 87% of those attributable to Gram-negative bacilli (33, 34). Mortality attributable to MNEC infections of the central nervous system is 10 to 15%, with long-term neurologic defect affecting up to 50% of survivors. Not surprisingly, the same organisms are implicated in neonatal bloodstream infections (BSI), with E. coli accounting for approximately 30% of all BSI and 80% of BSI caused by Gram-negative bacilli in this group. Importantly, 15 to 38% of infants with bacterial meningitis do not have positive blood cultures; therefore, a negative blood culture cannot be used to rule out CNS infection (33). MNEC infection also occurs in adult patients, specifically those with underlying immunocompromise and the elderly, where E. coli is the second leading cause of hospital and community-onset bacteremia behind only S. aureus (18).

Among MNEC, 90% of meningitis isolates and 60% of BSI isolates belong to one of 12 LPS O antigen serotypes, many of which are also shared with UPEC (55). This finding suggests potentially increased serum resistance and/or decreased immunogenicity for these O serotypes, which contributes to extraintestinal survival and pathogenesis. It also enables the potential for development of a vaccine targeted against MNEC serotypes. Another feature of MNEC is expression of the capsular K1 antigen, which is present on 80 to 90% of isolates recovered from cases of neonatal meningitis (65). In addition to serum resistance, K1 capsule promotes intracellular survival and traversal of the blood-brain barrier (18). Additional virulence factors including invasins (ibeA/B) and cytotoxic necrotizing factor 1 (cnf1) are present in many MNEC isolates and have demonstrated a role in blood-brain barrier traversal (18, 66). In vitro diagnostic tests have taken advantage of genetic markers such as K1 to specifically target MNEC in cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) specimens (67).

sect3.title: Diarrheagenic E. coli
sect3.para: Acute gastroenteritis is a common condition accounting for 1.5 million unscheduled outpatient encounters per year. The majority of these are attributable to viral infections, but diarrheagenicE. coli account for nearly 10% (>200,000 cases/year in the US) of all bacterial foodborne infections leading to diarrhea (27). There are five principal types of diarrheagenic E. coli: STEC, (including enterohemorrhagic E. coli [EHEC]), enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC), EPEC, enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC), and enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC). These pathogens express specific factors including adhesins, invasins, and cytotoxins that target the gastric epithelium, causing cell damage or osmotic dysregulation resulting in the watery or bloody diarrhea characteristic of each type of diarrheagenic E. coli. In some cases, virulence factors characteristic of more than one diarrheagenic E. coli type are present in the same isolate, creating a more pathogenic strain capable of causing more severe disease.

STEC and EHEC STEC, also known as verocytotoxin-producing E. coli (VTEC), was originally recognized for its ability to induce cytopathic effect in cultured African green monkey kidney cells (Vero cells). All STEC isolates encode Shiga toxin 1 (stx1) and/or 2 (stx2), which were named for their close relation to the cytotoxin encoded by Shigella dysenteriae type 1 (68). Shiga toxins specifically target endothelial cells in the GI tract and microvasculature of the renal glomeruli, where they arrest protein synthesis (68). Endothelial cell death leads to the characteristic bloody diarrhea often observed in STEC infections and enables migration of Stx into the bloodstream, where subsequent damage to renal microvasculature results in hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) (68). The clinical hallmarks of HUS include microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute renal failure. STEC strains that cause hemorrhagic colitis and HUS are further designated as EHEC. In addition to Stx, EHEC encode the LEE locus (see “Enteropathogenic E. coli,” below), which mediates tight binding to the gastric epithelium. Improved adherence combined with Stx production contributes to increased severity of GI symptoms associated with EHEC. Stx1 and Stx2 share 50 to 60% protein homology but are immunologically distinct and vary in toxicity (68). While stx1 is associated with mild disease, variants of stx2 (e.g., stx2a, stx2d) have been linked to severe bloody diarrhea and increased incidence of HUS (68, 69).

Shiga toxin 1 or 2 has been identified in >250E. coli O serotypes, of which approximately one-half have been connected to diarrheal illness in humans (70) (Table 2). STEC serotype O157 has the highest disease incidence worldwide, accounting for 30 to 80% of all STEC infections (70). This includes 65,000 to 75,000 cases per year in the United states alone (27, 71). The predominance of STEC O157 is likely attributable to its extremely low infectious dose of 50 to 200 CFU, which differentiates it from other STEC serotypes (69). STEC O157 causes both sporadic and outbreak-associated infections, including 35 to 45 outbreaks annually in the United States (71). Ground beef is the source of 40% of foodborne outbreaks of STEC O157, but contaminated produce and dairy products have also been frequently implicated as vehicles in large multistate foodborne outbreaks (71, 72). The low infectious dose also enables person-to-person transmission and transmission from environmental reservoirs including lakes contaminated with agricultural runoff. STEC O157 is prominent and historically has been the focus of diagnostic tests because of an increased association with severe bloody diarrhea and progression to life-threatening HUS. Specifically, infection with STEC O157 is associated with a 17 to 46% hospitalization rate, 4 to 6% incidence of HUS, and a mortality rate of 0.5% (27, 71, 73). Among patients who develop HUS, the overall mortality was 4.6%, with the highest mortality observed in persons >60 years of age (33.3%) and decreasing to 3% for children under 5 years of age (73). Conversely, development of HUS was more frequent in children under the age of 5 (15.3%) and fell to just 1.2% in adults age 18 to 59.

The importance of non-O157 STEC serotypes in both mild and severe acute gastroenteritis, including HUS, continues to emerge. In the United States, the incidence of reported non-O157 STEC infections has been steadily increasing since 2005 owing to expanded incorporation of ELISA and molecular methods for the direct detection of Stx toxin or thestx gene(s) in diarrheal stools. Currently, approximately 60% of reported STEC infections in the United States are caused by non-O157 serotypes (74). Similarly, in Argentina, Australia, and Germany, non-O157 serotypes account for the majority of STEC infections (70). In the United States and globally, serotypes O26, O103, O111, O121, and O145 are among the most frequent serotypes identified aside from O157 and are associated with increased incidence of HUS compared to other serotypes, ranging from 3 to 22% (69, 70, 74, 75). Clinically, infection with serotype O157 is more frequently associated with bloody diarrhea (71 to 97%) compared to non-O157 STEC (42 to 57%), while other symptoms including fever and abdominal pain are equivalent (70). Importantly, non-O157 STEC accounts for 16 to 43% of HUS globally (76). The proportion of HUS caused by non-O157 serotypes mirrors the prevalence of O157 and non-O157 serotypes isolated from symptomatic patients; therefore, countries with the highest proportion of non-O157 STEC also have the highest proportion of HUS caused by non-O157 serotypes (70). These data suggest that the presence of specific virulence factors (e.g., stx2a, eae) is a better predictor of disease severity than serotype; however, these genes are more common in some serotypes than others, and this varies by geographic region (69, 70). Indeed, one study found the odds ratio of developing HUS to be 5.8 for STEC encoding eae and 9.6 for STEC encoding stx2 when compared to STEC lacking these genes (75). Due to the increased awareness of severe disease caused by non-O157 STEC, as well as increasing incidence of these infections, the Joint Commission introduced Standard QSA.04.06.01 in 2013. This standard requires laboratories to perform tests that specifically detect Shiga toxin or the genes encoding the toxins for all patients with community-acquired diarrhea, to identify non-O157 STEC.

ETEC. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) strains produce heat-labile and/or heat-stable enterotoxins that define the pathotype and are central to pathogenesis. Heat-labile toxin (LT) is an AB5 subunit toxin encoded by eltA or eltB that shares approximately 80% identity with cholera toxin. LT induces overproduction of cyclic AMP in intestinal epithelial cells, which leads to dysregulation of the CFTR chloride ion channel and fluid loss (30, 77). Heat-stable toxin (ST) induces the production of intracellular cGMP, ultimately resulting in dysregulation of multiple ion channels, leading to fluid loss and impaired reabsorption (30, 77). The proportion of ETEC isolates containing LT, ST, or both toxins varies widely by geographic region, year, and study. In general, ST is present in 45 to 85% of ETEC, LT is present in 50 to 98% of ETEC, and both toxins are present in 15 to 60% of ETEC isolates (77). Production of either toxin is sufficient to cause disease, and production of both does not increase severity of symptoms (77). Colonization of the GI tract is mediated by a combination of >20 fimbrial and nonfimbrial adhesins that enable adherence to intestinal epithelial cells, aggregation of ETEC, and initiation of biofilm formation. These colonization factors (CFs) are plasmid encoded and are absent from 30 to 50% of ETEC isolates. Together, the differences in activity among individual LT types and variation in CFs may explain the continuum of symptom severity and asymptomatic carriage observed in patients with ETEC-positive stool.

Clinically, ETEC infection results in watery, nonbloody diarrhea that is often accompanied by vomiting in both children and adults (77). Subtropical and tropical regions of the developing world are areas of endemicity, owing largely to inadequate sanitation and water treatment practices. An estimated 840 million cases of ETEC occur worldwide annually, with 25 to 35% being children under the age of 4 (30). In regions of the developing world, it is estimated that children will have 0.5 to 1.5 ETEC infections per year (30). Asymptomatic carriage of ETEC is common in children in regions of endemicity. Case-controlled studies have demonstrated carriage rates of 8 to 19% in children under the age of 5 (77). Repeated exposure to ETEC may contribute to partial immunity, resulting in the high asymptomatic carriage rates observed in this population. Infected humans are the primary reservoir for ETEC, and transmission is fecal-oral. ETEC infections peak seasonally during the warm months and following monsoon season when surface water may be contaminated in regions of endemicity (77). Other vehicles of transmission include food prepared by infected individuals, contaminated drinking water, and produce washed or irrigated with contaminated water (30). In the developed world, ETEC infections are diagnosed primarily in individuals returning from regions of endemicity and account for 20 to 40% of “traveler’s diarrhea.” While less common, significant outbreaks have also been reported in the United States and other developed nations. These were related to imported produce, poor hand hygiene among food preparers, and improper food storage (30, 78). Recent implementation of multiplex panels for the detection of enteric pathogens has detected ETEC in 0.5 to 2.0% of symptomatic patients in developed countries, raising awareness of this pathogen in patients without significant travel history (79, 80). Importantly, additional bacterial or viral pathogens were identified in 80 to 93% of these specimens, calling into question the contribution of ETEC to disease and the clinical significance of these results (79, 81).

EPEC. Enteropathogenic E. coli was initially recognized as a common cause of infantile diarrhea in 1945. EPEC strains do not encode classical enterotoxins and are not invasive; rather, they are defined by their unique ability to induce architectural changes within intestinal epithelial cells and microvilli. These lesions are known as attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions because of the tight adherence of EPEC to microvilli followed by induction of pedestal-like protrusions rising from intestinal epithelial cells. The pathogenesis of A/E lesions results from a chromosomally encoded cluster of genes known as the locus of attachment and effacement (LEE). The LEE locus encodes tir, a trans-located intimin receptor which integrates into the host cell membrane and is surface exposed in the intestinal lumen. A second LEE-encoded protein called intimin (eae) is expressed on the bacterial cell membrane and binds tightly to Tir. In this way, EPEC mediates its own specific receptor binding to host cells. Other effectors encoded by LEE modulate actin polymerization to aid in pedestal formation, cause dysregulation of aquaporins leading to cellular fluid loss and diarrhea, disrupt cellular tight junctions, and aid in immune evasion (30, 82). Additional virulence factors are encoded on an E. coli adherence factor (EAF) plasmid. Most notable are the type IV bundle-forming pili (bfp), which mediate initial attachment to the intestinal epithelium, and perABC, which encodes transcriptional activators of bfp and the LEE locus (30). EPEC strains that encode LEE and contain the EAF plasmid are referred to as “typical EPEC,” while those lacking the EAF plasmid are referred to as “atypical EPEC” (30, 82).

EPEC is a significant pathogen associated with persistent nonbloody diarrhea in young children which can be severe and may be accompanied by fever and vomiting (82, 83). Like other enteropathogenic E. coli, the major reservoir is the GI tract of humans and other mammals. The infectious dose of EPEC is high, ranging from 108 to 1010 viable organisms, which reduces its transmissibility and ability to cause significant outbreaks (30, 84). However, poor hygiene and close contact such as occurs in day care facilities likely increase risk of transmission in both developing and developed countries (30). Typical EPEC isolates belong to serotypes O55, O86, O114, O27, and O142, while atypical EPEC are commonly O26, O55, O86, O111, O119, and O128 (30). Both typical and atypical EPEC have been implicated in endemic and epidemic gastroenteritis (82). Based on culture and serotype analysis, the prevalence of EPEC in symptomatic patients is 8 to 10% but can be as high as 15% in patients with severe diarrhea requiring hospitalization (82, 83). Importantly, not all isolates in these serogroups harbor LEE (i.e., are not EPEC), and EPEC have been identified in over 200 additional O serotypes. Together, these factors limit the utility of culture and serotyping for diagnosis of EPEC-associated diarrhea.

The introduction of molecular tests that specifically target theeae gene has enabled sensitive and accurate identification of EPEC in stool specimens. These tests have identified EPEC in 12 to 25% of stool specimens obtained from symptomatic adult and pediatric patients, suggesting an underappreciation of EPEC-associated diarrhea when using culture methods (79–81). Use of molecular diagnostics reinforces earlier associations of EPEC with pediatric diarrhea, noting over 45% positivity in children ages 1 to 5, but also 12 to 22% positivity in symptomatic adults (79). While EPEC is clearly common in adult patients, its significance is difficult to assess. Approximately 48 to 54% of diarrheal stools containing EPEC contain additional potential pathogens including norovirus, Campylobacter spp., or other diarrheagenic E. coli (79, 81, 85). Studies comparing symptomatic and asymptomatic adults have found a similar prevalence of 23 to 37% in both groups (85). In the pediatric population, some studies have demonstrated significantly higher positivity in symptomatic patients versus controls, while others have demonstrated similar prevalence in both groups (83, 86). This discordance may be the result of differences in pathogenicity among common EPEC serotypes or differences in bacterial load in the GI tract. Quantitative PCR targeting the eae gene in EPEC demonstrated a slightly higher bacterial load in symptomatic children than controls (299 versus 29 CFU/mg, P = 0.016) overall; however, the difference was only statistically significant in children <1 year of age and only when EPEC was the sole pathogen detected (87). Finally, among immunocompromised patients, the percentage of individuals with EPEC detected in stool specimens was similar in those with history of diarrhea (20%) versus those with no history of diarrhea (23%), as well as in a matched asymptomatic immunocompetent cohort (23%) (85).

EIEC. EIEC shares a high degree of genetic and phenotypic similarity with Shigella spp. Cellular invasion, intracellular survival, and direct spread of EIEC to adjacent host cells are mediated by multiple gene clusters located on the virulence plasmid pINV. This plasmid is found in all EIEC and Shigella isolates, but was likely acquired by each species independently (88). Destruction of endothelial cells results in the bloody diarrhea sometimes observed in EIEC infections. Chromosomally encoded enterotoxins set2 and sigA further potentiate cellular fluid loss, leading to watery diarrhea. Further details of this process can be found in the chapter section below describing the clinical significance of Shigella. Importantly, the effector ipaH is present in multiple copies on both pINV and the bacterial chromosome and has been used as a target for molecular tests that identify EIEC and Shigella in stool specimens (30, 79).

The epidemiology and clinical impact of EIEC are difficult to ascertain because of its close relationship toShigella and the difficulty in distinguishing EIEC from Shigella by using biochemical, phenotypic, and molecular methods. Definitive differentiation requires multiple tests including PCR detection of genes more common in Shigella and serotyping analysis, though cross-reactivity between EIEC and some Shigella serotypes is common (30, 88). The reservoir for EIEC is the GI tract of humans and non-human primates. Transmission is primarily fecal-oral resulting from poor hand hygiene, but small foodborne outbreaks have been reported in Africa, Asia, and the Americas including the United States (30, 88). This contrasts with Shigella, which is a well-documented cause of food- and waterborne outbreaks affecting 150 to 200 million people globally on an annual basis. Overall, EIEC may account for 10% or fewer of the total symptomatic infections attributed to EIEC and Shigella spp. combined (89). The stark contrast in cases of EIEC versus Shigella results from two key factors. First, clinical symptoms associated with EIEC infection, including the presence of blood in stool, are often mild when compared to those accompanying classic Shigella infection and likely contribute to underreporting of infection. This may be the result of reduced expression of ipa and several other virulence genes that reduce invasiveness, cell-to-cell spread, and the inflammatory response to EIEC (90). Second, the reduced invasiveness of EIEC results in an infective dose that is 1,000 to 10,000 times higher than Shigella, which in turn reduces the transmissibility of EIEC (91). Treatment of EIEC infection should be driven by symptom severity and individual patient risk factors such as age, comorbidities, and immunosuppression. Mild cases often resolve with only supportive care and oral rehydration therapy. The use of antibiotics may be appropriate for severe cases and in patients with identified risk factors. Choice of antibiotic should be based on results of susceptibility testing or local antibiograms but may include ciprofloxacin or ceftriaxone (30).

EAEC. The EAEC are a heterogeneous group of E. coli that share a common mechanism of pathogenesis based on enhanced adherence, biofilm formation, and production of cyto- and enterotoxins (30, 92). Bacterial colonies adhere to each other and to the surface of cultured cell lines, plastic, or other surfaces in what is referred to as a “stacked brick” architecture (92). Mediators of biofilm formation are encoded on the virulence plasmid pAA (30, 92). EAEC encode multiple toxins chromosomally and on pAA (e.g., set, sepA, pet) that potentiate fluid loss, many of which are found in other diarrheagenic E. coli and Shigella spp. (30, 92). The aggR gene resides on pAA and encodes a global regulator of biofilm and toxin expression. aggR has been used as a molecular target for diagnostic tests that identify pathogenic E. coli (30, 92). E. coli strains that carry aggR are referred to as “typical” EAEC, while those that lack aggR, but maintain the EAEC aggregative phenotype, are referred to as “atypical” EAEC. Atypical EAEC account for as many as 25% of EAEC infections and, despite lacking this global regulator, retain the ability to form biofilm and cause acute diarrhea (93).

Typical symptoms of EAEC infection include persistent, nonbloody, watery diarrhea. Chronic colonization and biofilm formation can disrupt normal intestinal function and lead to secondary sequelae of malnutrition and growth retardation even in the absence of diarrheal symptoms (92). The impact of EAEC infection is greatest in children living in regions of endemicity, where the number of symptomatic infections can surpass those caused by ETEC (94). Individuals with uncontrolled HIV infection may also be at increased risk for persistent and severe diarrhea resulting from EAEC infection (30, 92). Humans are the primary reservoir for EAEC and transmission is likely via the fecal-oral route. A high infective dose of 108 to 1010 CFU is required to cause symptomatic infection; however, lower doses are likely sufficient to initiate subclinical infection and asymptomatic carriage (84, 92). Contaminated water supplies are likely a major source of infection. EAEC was detected in 4 to 36% of water sources tested in Australia and Bangladesh (92). Fresh foods contaminated by use of unclean water for washing or irrigation, or by infected individuals during preparation, have also been implicated in outbreaks (30, 92, 94). In the developed world, EAEC has long been recognized as a cause of traveler’s diarrhea, but the implementation of molecular diagnostic panels has increased awareness of EAEC as a potential cause of sporadic acute gastroenteritis in healthy adults and children without travel history (79–81). These studies place EAEC among the top four most common enteric pathogens detected in diarrheal stools (EPEC, Campylobacter, Clostridium difficile, EAEC), accounting for 5 to 7% of total positive results. Like other diarrheagenic E. coli, EAEC is frequently found in stools containing other potential pathogens (79, 81). Further, comparative studies of children living in areas of endemicity have demonstrated a high rate of asymptomatic carriage and similar overall prevalence of EAEC in symptomatic cases and controls (92).

An important development in the evolution of EAEC as a pathogen is the ability to acquire additional virulence factors through bacterial conjugation or phage transduction. This exchange of genetic material has resulted in EAEC acquiring virulence determinants typical of otherE. coli pathovars such as UPEC, EIEC, and EHEC (92). The most notable of these is the acquisition of Shiga toxin stx2 by a strain of EAEC that resulted in two large foodborne outbreaks in Germany in 2001 and 2011. These isolates belonged to serotype O104, which is typical of EAEC but infrequently associated with EHEC (95). The increased pathogenic potential of this strain was demonstrated by the 3,842 reported cases of diarrhea, 855 (22%) of which were complicated by HUS (92).

Other diarrheagenic E. coli. Ongoing studies of E. coli isolates obtained from patients with diarrheal illness have identified two additional groups of E. coli that share phenotypic, pathologic, or serologic similarities. The diffusely aggregative E. coli (DAEC) are named for their diffuse adherence pattern to cultured epithelial cells. DAEC tend to cover a larger surface of host cells, as opposed to aggregating in a focal pattern like EAEC or EPEC (30). Specific receptor-mediated binding by DAEC induces structural and functional changes in epithelial cells, including loss of microvilli, which ultimately results in diarrhea. The cytotoxin sat is produced by some but not all DAEC strains. No correlation between sat and diarrhea has been found in adults; however, in children, expression of sat is more common in children with diarrhea than controls who harbor DAEC lacking sat (96). Asymptomatic carriage is common in older children and adults, and DAEC does not appear to be a primary cause of diarrhea in these groups. However, chronic colonization has been suggested to contribute to inflammatory bowel disease and Crohn’s disease (30). Acute symptomatic DAEC infection is observed most commonly in children <5 years of age, potentially due to intestinal barriers and other host defenses that are not yet fully developed (96). In this group, DAEC has been isolated from up to 23% of stool specimens obtained from symptomatic patients (30). Reporting of the actual epidemiology and incidence of DAEC is hampered by the lack of a true definition of this pathovar and genetic heterogeneity among individual isolates. Identification based on serotype analysis may provide some additional value, as demonstrated by a study that found 19 DAEC serotypes unique to patients with diarrhea while other serotypes were found in both symptomatic patients and controls (30).

Adherent invasiveE. coli (AIEC) strains are currently defined based solely on the phenotypic invasive and inflammatory characteristics associated with infection. Whole-genome studies have identified up to 35 potential pathogenicity islands encoding various pili, surface adhesins, secretion systems, iron acquisition, and regulatory proteins, some of which likely contribute to the pathogenesis of AIEC (30). A correlation between Crohn’s disease (CD) and AIEC infection has been recognized. Multiple studies have isolated AIEC from 30 to 40% of patients with CD as compared to 0 to 6% of asymptomatic controls (30). The basis for this association may be enhanced expression of specific receptors on the intestinal epithelium of individuals with CD that are targets for AIEC adherence. Future studies are needed to specifically define the AIEC pathovar and determine the epidemiology and significance of this organism in diarrheal illness.

sect1.title: Taxonomy
sect1.para: The genusShigella is composed of four species: S. dysenteriae, S. flexneri, S. boydii, and S. sonnei. Chromosome size (4.3–4.8 Mbp), number of open reading frames (4,334–4,557), and GC content (50.9–51.2%) among the four species are similar and are indistinguishable from the same features in E. coli (97). Genetic studies have demonstrated as little as 1.12% sequence divergence between chromosomal housekeeping genes common to prototypical E. coli and Shigella isolates (98). This relatedness is evident in phylogenetic trees that position Shigella species among diarrheagenic E. coli isolates (99). The primary difference between E. coli and Shigella is the ability of Shigella to actively invade the intestinal epithelium. Invasion and intracellular survival are mediated by the presence of a virulence plasmid (pINV) that is present in all Shigella spp. as well as EIEC. Biochemically, Shigella can be differentiated from E. coli based on an inability to ferment lactose, lack of indole production by the majority of serotypes, and lack of motility; however, EIEC and other “nonreactive” E. coli isolates often share these phenotypic and biochemical traits (98). Therefore, a combination of biochemical and serological test results is necessary to correctly identify Shigella spp. and differentiate them from inactive E. coli (Table 3).

The taxonomy ofShigella has traditionally been driven by serotype, with each of the four species constituting a unique serogroup: S. dysenteriae, serogroup A; S. flexneri, serogroup B; S. boydii, serogroup C; and S. sonnei, serogroup D (100). Each serogroup is further divided into 14 to 20 O-antigen serotypes with the exception of serogroup D (S. sonnei), which contains only one serotype (Table 4) (100). A number of these serotypes are closely related to specific EIEC O-antigen serogroups, which may complicate definitive serologic identification of some isolates. Within serogroup A, S. dysenteriae serotype 1 harbors a chromosomally encoded Shiga toxin (stx1a) that underlies the severe diarrhea and HUS often associated with these infections (100). Taxonomic classification and identification based solely on serotype is complicated by cross-reactivity between Shigella serotypes in each serogroup and specific EIEC serotypes (30).

Taxonomic studies using a molecular approach have organized the genus into three distinct genetic clusters (C1, C2, and C3), with C1 further divided into three subclusters (SC1 through SC3) (99). Multiple Shigella species/serogroups are found in each of the three clusters; however, subclusters within C1 are composed of primarily one species/serogroup. Of interest, S. sonnei, S. dysenteriae serotypes 1, 8, and 10, and S. boydii serotype 13 fall outside of the main C1–C3 clusters. Among Shigella species S. dysenteriae serotype 1 clustered most closely with EHEC, supporting the hypothesis that a specific genetic background is prerequisite for acquisition of Shiga toxin-encoding genes (99). The remaining two S. dysenteriae serotypes (serotypes 8 and 10) that failed to cluster with Shigella demonstrated greater genetic similarity to EIEC and UPEC isolates (99). S. boydii serotype 13 was only distantly related to the other Shigella serotypes, which is consistent with earlier reports that place this serotype in close genetic proximity to Escherichia albertii (both encode intimin—i.e., eae—and lack the virulence plasmid common to Shigella species) (99, 101). Combined, these data suggest that traditional serologic classification does not reflect accurate phylogeny for all Shigella serotypes. Genetic analysis provides better taxonomic discrimination between serotypes within each of the four species/serogroups and raises questions about the current classification of some serotypes as Shigella species.

sect1.title: Description of the Genus
sect1.para: Members of the genusShigella are nonmotile, non-spore-forming, noncapsulated, Gram-negative bacilli. All Shigella are facultative anaerobes and are capable of growth on common laboratory culture media including Trypticase soy agar (TSA) with or without blood supplement, MacConkey agar, and Trypticase soy broth (TSB) (21, 98). Several selective and differential media also support the growth of Shigella and are often used for primary screening or culture enrichment (see “Specimen Enrichment for Stool Culture,” below). On blood agar, Shigella is apparent as small, circular, translucent, domed colonies after 16 to 24 h incubation at 35°C. Shigella is susceptible to desiccation and acidic pH, which impacts recovery of the bacterium in unpreserved stool specimens, where acid produced by other resident bacteria rapidly lowers the local pH. Biochemically, Shigella reduces nitrate to nitrite and ferments glucose to acid end products, but does not produce gas (21, 98) (Table 1). Shigella spp. do not ferment other common sugars including lactose or sucrose, do not hydrolyze esculin, do not form H2S, and do not produce lysine decarboxylase. Within the genus, only S. sonnei and S. boydii serogroup 13 are positive for ornithine decarboxylase. S. sonnei may also ferment lactose upon extended incubation (>24 h).
